results.title: Blue like an orange
results.brief_description: Puppets of the Orient and the Occident are presented in this UNESCO contribution to understanding between East and West. Scenes of puppet plays in India, Japan, Singapore, Malaysia, Laos, Poland, Czechoslovakia and the United States today. The presentations illustrate the great variety of the traditions which have survived for thousands of years. Also includes archival footage of Jim Henson and “the muppets” including a very early Kermit.

results.title: Waistlines and lifelines
results.creator_credit: John Banks, Advent Films and Russell Gibbs
results.brief_description: Ron has a weight problem. He tries massage and the crash diet, but to no avail. A heart attack scare sends him to his doctor, who recommends graded exercises and consultation with a dietician.

results.title: The Vision of William Blake (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Morse Films, British Film Institute Experimental Film Fund and Guy Brenton
results.brief_description: Filmed in four museums that contain major collections of Blake’s writings and paintings, this documentary by Guy Brenton explores the anguish of Blake’s prophetic world, Music by Ralph Vaughan Williams, and narration and poems read by Bernard Miles and Robert Speight.

results.title: Blue Ice
results.creator_credit: Phillip Garth Law, Film Australia and External Affairs
results.brief_description: A record of the 1954 Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition, which relieved the scientific stations at Macquarie and Heard Islands and established a new station at Mawson on MacRobertson Land in Australian Antarctic Territory. The film describes the expedition’s departure from Melbourne in December 1953 and follows its 12,000 mile journey through high seas and pack ice, providing an insight into daily life at the stations and the challenges presented by often-difficult conditions. There is stunning footage of towering icebergs and masses of penguins as well as aerial reconnaissance and surveillance.

results.title: The Blowfly menace
results.creator_credit: A. C. McKay BVSc and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: For farmers and graziers this study of the life-cycle of the green blowfly and other flies associated with blowfly strike in sheep, and demonstrations of various methods of control, should prove both useful and interesting.

results.title: Birds and billabongs
results.creator_credit: Charles P. Mountford and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Records the 1948 Arnhem Land Expedition, sponsored by the national Geographic Society, the Smithsonian Institute of America and the Commonwealth Government. Shows various types of birds found in Arnhem Land including terns, plovers, Burdekin ducks, sharp-tailed sand pipers, geese, royal spoonbills, the snake bird, brolgas, white necked heron, the egret and the lotus bird. The sound track includes actual recordings of bird song.

results.title: The Billiard room
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Joe Scully, Film Australia and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adults Learning”.
Designed to promote group discussion on the problems of the adult learning process in management-staff relations through a discussion between a potential university dropout, his friend and an onlooker. It suggests that not all learning occurs in the classroom. This film should not be screened by itself as a documentary. It does not provide direct information on the process of adult learning. It is a teaching aid which provides a basis for discussion.

results.title: Beyond the pack ice
results.brief_description: Describes life on the inhospitable Antarctic continent. Animal and plant life is sparse but man has established himself. At the Mawson research station intensive study programmes include auroral physics, meteorology and medicine. The four months of daylight are packed with outdoor activities. Shows the annual arrival of the supply ship from Australia and describes some of the emotions of the men on the expedition.

results.title: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Film Associates
results.brief_description: This 1960’s film is about the communication gap between two generations: teenagers and young adults on the one hand, and the generation of those over thirty - “the establishment”. The teenagers’ use of LSD and other drugs is only one of the symptoms of this communication gap. A group of parents desperately seek help in order to understand what has gone wrong. The film is an attempt to go “beyond LSD” and is intended to stimulate discussion amongst high school students, college students, teachers and parents. Ample involuntary hilarity can result from viewing this great hysterical/historical document. Starting as a raucous celluloid freak-out, the film presents its square’s-eye view of the “Generation Gap” through the fictive device of a round table of pod people, each alike in their helmet-hair and cat’s eye glasses. The production crew of this film was primarily made up of teenagers and young adults. Music by ‘The Stayns.’ A minor masterpiece of psychedelic cinema.
